review.title: Uncovering Causality from Multivariate Hawkes Integrated Cumulants
review.abstract: We design a new nonparametric method that allows one to estimate the matrix of integrated kernels of a multivariate Hawkes process. This matrix not only encodes the mutual influences of each nodes of the process, but also disentangles the causality relationships between them. Our approach is the first that leads to an estimation of this matrix without any parametric modeling and estimation of the kernels themselves. A consequence is that it can give an estimation of causality relationships between nodes (or users), based on their activity timestamps (on a social network for instance), without knowing or estimating the shape of the activities lifetime. For that purpose, we introduce a moment matching method that fits the third-order integrated cumulants of the process. We show on numerical experiments that our approach is indeed very robust to the shape of the kernels, and gives appealing results on the MemeTracker database.

metadata.title: Uncovering Causality from Multivariate Hawkes Integrated Cumulants

sections.text: Keywords: Hawkes Process, Causality Conclusion, Cumulants, Generalized Method of Moments

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In many cases, one has to deal with data containing a very large number of irregular timestamped events that are recorded in continuous time. (These events may reflect, for example, the activity of users in a social network, see Subrahmanian et al. (2016), the radio frequency variations of signals in the financial world, see Bacry et al. (2015), the shocks and aftershocks in geophysics, see Ogata (1998), criminal activity, see Mohler et al. (2011), or the position of genes in genomics, see Reynaud-Bouret and Schbath (2010). The sequence of precise timestamps carries a large amount of information about the dynamics of the underlying systems. In this context, multidimensional counting processes play a paramount role. Within this framework, it is an important task to restore the reciprocal influence of nodes (i.e.) by making the different components of the counting process use of their time-sensitive patterns.

sections.heading: 2 NPHC: The Non Parametric Hawkes Cumulant method
sections.text: In this section we give the background to the integrals of Hawkes nuclei and integrals of Hawkes cumulants. Then we explain how the NPHC method enables the estimation of G.

(2015) or Hawkes and Oakes (1974), gij can simply be interpreted as the average total number of events of the node i, whose direct ancestor is a particular event of the node j (by direct we mean that interactions mediated by another incident are not counted). In this respect, G not only describes the mutual influences between the nodes, but also quantifies their direct causal relationships. sections.heading: 2.5 Complexity of the algorithm
sections.text: Compared to existing state-of-the-art methods for estimating the core functions, e.g. the ordinary differential equation-based (ODE) algorithm in Zhou et al. (2013a), the Granger causality-based algorithm in Xu et al. (2016), the ADM4 algorithm in Zhou et al. (2013b) and the Wiener-Hopf-based algorithm in Bacry and Muzy (2016), our method has a very competitive complexity. This can be understood by the fact that these methods estimate the core functions, whereas in NPHC we only estimate their integrals. The ODE-based algorithm is an EM algorithm that parameterizes the core function with M base functions, discrediting each on L-points. Basic functions are updated after solving M Euler Lagrange equations.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we introduce a simple non-parametric method (the NPHC algorithm) that leads to a fast and robust estimation of the matrix G of the core integrals of a multivariate Hawkes process, which encodes the Granger causality between the nodes. This method is based on matching the integrated order 2 and order 3 empirical cumulants, which represent the simplest global observational values that contain enough information to restore the matrixG. Since this matrix fully takes into account the self- and cross-influences of the process nodes (which agents or users can represent in applications), our approach can of course be used to quantify the degree of endogeneity of a system and to detect the causality structure of a network. By conducting numerical experiments with very different core forms, we show that the baselines, which include either parametric or non-parametric approaches, are very useful in order to model miscellaneous specifications, these NHC results and to ensure that the results are classical and NHC-reliable.

sections.text: This work benefited from the support of the Chair "Changing markets," the CMAP École Polytechnique and the École Polytechnique Fund Raising - Data Science Initiative.The authors thank Marcello Rambaldi for fruitful discussions on the experiments with order book data.

The Hawkes process introduced in Hawkes (1971) corresponds to an autoregressive structure of the intensities in order to capture self-excitation and cross-excitation of nodes, which is a phenomenon typically observed, for instance, in social networks, see for instance Crane and Sornette (2008).

(2015), they choose φij(t) = αijh(t) with αij ∈ R+ quantifies the intensity of the influence of j on i and h(t) a (normalized) function that characterizes the time-profile of this influence and that is shared by all couples of nodes (i, j) (most often, it is chosen to be either exponential h(t) = βe−βt or power law h(t) = βt−(β+1)). Both approaches are, most of the time, highly non-realistic. On the one hand there is a priori no reason for assuming that the time-profile of the influence of a node j on a node i does not depend on the pair (i, j). On the other hand, assuming an exponential shape or a power law shape for a kernel arbitrarily imposes an event impact that is always instantly maximal and that can only decrease with time, while in practice, there may exist a latency between an event and its maximal impact. In order to have more flexibility on the shape of the kernels, nonparametric estimation can be considered. Expectation-Maximization algorithms can be found in Lewis and Mohler (2011) (for d = 1) or in Zhou et al.

On the other hand, assuming an exponential shape or a power law shape for a kernel arbitrarily imposes an event impact that is always instantly maximal and that can only decrease with time, while in practice, there may exist a latency between an event and its maximal impact. In order to have more flexibility on the shape of the kernels, nonparametric estimation can be considered. Expectation-Maximization algorithms can be found in Lewis and Mohler (2011) (for d = 1) or in Zhou et al. (2013a) (d > 1).
An alternative method is proposed in Bacry and Muzy (2016) where the nonparametric estimation is formulated as a numerical solving of a Wiener-Hopf equation.

As it can be seen from the cluster representation of Hawkes processes (Hawkes and Oakes (1974)), this integral represents the mean total number of events of type i directly triggered by an event of type j, and then encodes a notion of causality.
1), such integral can be related to the Granger causality (Granger (1969)).

As it will be shown, this approach turns out to be particularly robust to the kernel shapes, which is not the case of all previous Hawkes-based approaches that aim causality recovery. We call this method NPHC (Non Parametric Hawkes Cumulant), since our approach is of nonparametric nature. We provide a theoretical analysis that proves the consistency of the NPHC estimator. Our proof is based on ideas from the theory of Generalized Method of Moments (GMM) but requires an original technical trick since our setting strongly departs from the standard parametric statistics with i.i.d observations. Note that moment and cumulant matching techniques proved particularly powerful for latent topic models, in particular Latent Dirichlet Allocation, see Podosinnikova et al. (2015). 1 Branching structure and Granger causality From the definition of Hawkes process as a Poisson cluster process, see Jovanović et al. (2015) or Hawkes and Oakes (1974), gij can be simply interpreted as the average total number of events of node i whose direct ancestor is a given event of node j (by direct we mean that interactions mediated by any other intermediate event are not counted).

1 Branching structure and Granger causality From the definition of Hawkes process as a Poisson cluster process, see Jovanović et al. (2015) or Hawkes and Oakes (1974), gij can be simply interpreted as the average total number of events of node i whose direct ancestor is a given event of node j (by direct we mean that interactions mediated by any other intermediate event are not counted).

Namely, introducing the counting function N i←j t that counts the number of events of i whose direct ancestor is an event of j, we know from Bacry et al. (2015) that E[dN i←j t ] = g E[dN j t ] = g Λdt, (2) where we introduced Λi as the intensity expectation, namely satisfying E[dN i t ] = Λidt.

Namely, introducing the counting function N i←j t that counts the number of events of i whose direct ancestor is an event of j, we know from Bacry et al. (2015) that E[dN i←j t ] = g E[dN j t ] = g Λdt, (2) where we introduced Λi as the intensity expectation, namely satisfying E[dN i t ] = Λidt. Note that Λi does not depend on time by stationarity ofN t, which is known to hold under the stability condition ‖G‖ < 1, where ‖G‖ stands for the spectral norm ofG. In particular, this condition implies the non-singularity of Id −G. Since the question of a real causality is too complex in general, most econometricians agreed on the simpler definition of Granger causality Granger (1969). Its mathematical formulation is a statistical hypothesis test: X causes Y in the sense of Granger causality if forecasting future values of Y is more successful while taking X past values into account.

In Eichler et al. (2016), it is shown that for N t a multivariate Hawkes process, N j t does not Granger-cause N i t w.

2 Integrated cumulants of the Hawkes process A general formula for the integral of the cumulants of a multivariate Hawkes process is provided in Jovanović et al. (2015). As explained below, for the purpose of our method, we only need to consider cumulants up to the third order.
Using the martingale representation from Bacry and Muzy (2016) or the Poisson cluster process representation from Jovanović et al.

2 Consistency First, let’s remind a useful theorem for consistency in GMM from Newey and McFadden (1994). Theorem 4.

2 Consistency First, let’s remind a useful theorem for consistency in GMM from Newey and McFadden (1994). Theorem 4.1. If there is a function Q0(θ) such that (i) Q0(θ) is uniquely maximized at θ0; (ii) Θ is compact; (iii) Q0(θ) is continuous; (iv) Q̂T (θ) converges uniformly in probability to Q0(θ), then θ̂T = arg max Q̂T (θ) P −→ θ0. metadata.abstractText: We design a new nonparametric method that allows one to estimate the matrix of integrated kernels of a multivariate Hawkes process. This matrix not only encodes the mutual influences of each node of the process, but also disentangles the causality relationships between them. Our approach is the first that leads to an estimation of this matrix without any parametric modeling and estimation of the kernels themselves. As a consequence, it can give an estimation of causality relationships between nodes (or users), based on their activity timestamps (on a social network for instance), without knowing or estimating the shape of the activities lifetime. For that purpose, we introduce a moment matching method that fits the second-order and the third-order integrated cumulants of the process. A theoretical analysis allows us to prove that this new estimation technique is consistent. Moreover, we show, on numerical experiments, that our approach is indeed very robust with respect to the shape of the kernels and gives appealing results on the MemeTracker database and on financial order book data.
